proc:Name.footnote: FY19 increase of $3.770 million is to account for roughly 564 service-common Table of Allowance items compared to the planned procurement of 282 items in FY18. These funds support the approved service-common Table Of Allowance requirements supporting End Strength Growth in order to meet Geographic Combatant Commanders (GCC) demands to support existing counter-terrorist, counter violent extremist organization, and Building Partner Capacity missions and operations. Disaggregated nature of current operations has SEAL elements deployed across the GCCs conducting combat or combat advise operations in austere environments with little-to-no established DoD infrastructure. These investments include but are not limited to the procurement of visual augmentation support items to include; small arms optics, night vision goggles, laser range finders, and illuminators. This materiel supports NSW core mission requirements and is essential to the readiness and battlefield effectiveness of NSW in winning the current fight against ISIS and other extremist elements.

The FY 2020 funding request was reduced by $0.611 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances. A Remote PUK will provide 2-3 months of on-site parts replacements for NSW Puma Operators deployed to remote and austere locations. NSW's past experience in these environments has demonstrated that the supply chain is lengthened beyond its ability to replace vital system parts in a timely manner. A Centralized PUK will be deployed to support multiple NSW Puma Operational teams from a centralized hub. Unlike a remote PUK, the centralized PUK will enable support for multiple operational elements for up to 6 months. As these support multiple teams, a more robust supply of parts is necessary as Naval supply chains cannot provide parts support quickly enough to remote locations ensure combat effectiveness of invaluable tactical ISR support.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Distance Support: A Navy Enterprise effort that combines people, processes and technology into a collaborative infrastructure without regard to geographic location. Distance Support (DS) is comprised of the following three components: Infrastructure, Content and Customer Relationship Management (CRM). Infrastructure provides the "transport" of DS applications and data to and from operating units and shore installations in support of various processes. Technology infrastructure also includes the data replication and shipboard IT servers that bring the DS functionality to the sailor. Content includes specific applications, systems and processes produced by various Navy communities of Interest. Customer Relationship Management (CRM) capabilities include the "Navy 311" Website, BMC Remedy Software, Shared Data Environment, Business Intelligence and Predictive Modeling software, Avaya telephony and Call Management System, and the Navy 311 Support Center, which is the hub of Distance Support, providing the single point of entry for support requests for fleet customers on a 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, 365 days per year basis (24/7/365).
The Navy Information Application Product Suite (NIAPS) is comprised of integrated hardware and Government off-the-shelf (GOTS) software that bring various workstations, storage, servers, applications and content into a common environment for shipboard deployment. NIAPS provides data compression and replication capability and is designed to re-host typically shore/web-based applications afloat to minimize bandwidth and provide maximum capability. NIAPS is comprised of 27 applications and databases launched from a single Distance Support (DS) Portal on NIAPS server. NIAPS runs applications specifically tailored to individual afloat units for training, career management, maintenance, technical drawings, logistics, human resources, as well as morale and welfare support (Quality of life) which are produced by various Navy functional organizations. NIAPS gives a ship access to critical applications and data using internal shipboard networks, which is faster and cheaper than using external bandwidth and satellite time.
Data Center Consolidation (DCC): DCC procures and installs data center hardware, software, and licenses for established Navy Enterprise Data Centers (NEDCs) and other approved hosting locations as part of the Department of Defense's Information Technology efficiency to consolidate and standardize the Navy's Data Center footprint. DCC will complete the data center consolidation effort in FY19.
SPAWAR IW Platform: Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command (SPAWAR) and PEOC4I Shore & Expeditionary Integration Program Office are recognized as the Navy's Command, Control, Communications, Computer, Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance / Information Technology (C4ISR/IT) integration Subject Matter Expert (SME) delivering Shore Information Warfare (IW) Platform Capabilities. Funding supports the identification and validation of C4ISR/IT system requirements and provides system of system architecture, integration and installation design plans tailored to deliver specific required Capability to Shore IW Platforms. Shore IW Platforms support assured Command and Control, voice, video and data communications, Precise Time and Astrometry. and intelligence support services that are critical to allowing the flow of information from Operational Commanders to the War Fighters both afloat and ashore. MILCON projects associated with Shore IW Platforms require complex planning based on the required capability which includes advanced planning, integration and installation of numerous C4ISR/IT systems across multiple programs of record that support Command Centers, Operations Centers and Master Telecommunication Facilities, CONUS and OCONUS.
Telephony: Tactical Voice and Video Communications and Modernization: The Department of Defense (DoD), Chief Information Officer (CIO) has prioritized the modernization of network infrastructure to be regionally based, centrally managed and cyber secure. This includes migrating existing infrastructure from Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) to Internet Protocol (IP) based communications to enable Unified Capabilities (UC). Telephony procures and integrates Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) hardware and software to meet the DoD-CIO TDM to IP mandate for the Navy. Program requirements include: Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), Voice over Secure Internet Protocol (VoSIP), Video Teleconferencing over Secure Internet Protocol (VTCoSIP), Telephony Unified Messaging System (TUMS), Regional Telephony Management System (RTMS), Navy Video Conferencing System (NVCS), NVCS Coalition (NVCS-C), Internet Protocol (IP) Trunking, Aegis Ashore, and Telephony systems infrastructure (e.g. cable plant). Telephony system installations and/or upgrades occur at facilities in accordance with requirements as identified by Navy Information Forces (NAVIFOR), Office of the Chief of Naval Operations (OPNAV), and Missile Defense Agency (MDA).
MILCON C4I Shore Based Enterprise Network Enhancements (Telephony): Funding additionally supports procurement and installation of mission related Telephony equipment at the following shore sites: - MILCON P-913: Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station (NCTAMS) Atlantic - MILCON P-621: NCTAMS Atlantic Det Rota Spain - MILCON P-131: NCTAMS Atlantic Det Souda Bay - MILCON P-130: Naval Computer and Telecommunications Station (NCTS) Sigonella Italy
MILCON Project P-013: Navy Information Operations Command, Hawaii (NIOC HI) performs all duties assigned by Commander Pacific Fleet (COMPACFLT), Fleet Cyber Command (FLTCYBERCOM) / Commander Tenth Fleet (COMTENTHFLT), Navy Information Forces (NAVIFOR), and the Director, National Security Agency. NIOC HI conducts and provides support to information warfare, cyber, signals intelligence, Information Operations (IO) and electronic warfare mission areas in the Pacific Fleet area of responsibility (PAC AOR). At the direction of United States Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM), FLTCYBERCOM / COMTENTHFLT will be deploying substantial Cyber Mission Forces to Oahu. NCTAMS PAC and NIOC HI require close collaboration and alignment between the elements of the intelligence community under NIOC HI and the network operations under NCTAMS PAC in a controlled environment. MILCON Project P-013 provides Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF) space for three PACOM Cyber Protection Teams, which currently has inadequate SCIF space to meet USCYBERCOM standards.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Distance Support NIAPS (-$0.085M): FY20 funds the procurement of software and all the associated labor for the tech refresh of the NIAPS software suite, patching, testing, and integration of new components to address obsolescence and cybersecurity vulnerabilities. FY20 also funds the procurement of Microsoft Windows 2012 and SQL Server 2012 licenses to support installation of NIAPS V3.0. NIAPS V3.0 replaces NIAPS 2.4.X, which utilizes end-of life software that is not PKI compliant, and meets newly established cybersecurity requirements to include renewal of Authority to Operate (ATO)s within the Risk Management Framework (RMF).
Data Center Consolidation (DCC)(-$3.235M): - No funding budgeted for FY20. DCC will complete the data center consolidation effort in FY19.
Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command (SPAWAR) Shore Information Warfare (IW) Platform (+$37.385M realignment)includes: - FY20 increase is a net zero realignment to correct appropriation designation from O&MN (AGSAG 1C1C) to OPN (Line Item 8161). - (+$35.615M) of this realignment supports advanced planning, system of systems architecture, and design and integration planning efforts associated with the following Shore IW Platform MILCON projects that deliver Command, Control, Communications, Computer, Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance / Information Technology (C4ISR/IT) Capability: P621 - Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station, Atlantic Det Rota (NCTAMS LANT Det Rota); P013 - Navy Information & Operations Center (NIOC) Hawaii; P130 - Naval Computer and Telecommunications Station, Sigonella (NCTS Sigonella); P913 - Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station, Atlantic, (NCTAMS LANT C4I); P001 - US Naval Observatory; P131 - NCTAMS LANT Det Souda Bay; and P649 - NCTS Guam. Each design is tailored to meet a required capability. The Shore and Expeditionary Program Office provides portfolio management of MILCON Shore IW Platform efforts to manage requirements as they change due to real world events and to ensure required capability is delivered on time and within cost. System integration designs range from integrating 20 to 80+ different systems at each Shore IW Platform. - (+$1.869M) provides funding for support costs directly related to SPAWAR Shore IW Platform efforts.
Telephony Tactical Voice and Video communications and Modernization (-$4.625M) includes: - Telephony Program of Record (-$0.201M): Funding decrease between FY19 and FY20 is due to decreased IP Conversion efforts in FY20. In FY20, the program will continue procurement and installation of Internet Protocol (IP) based equipment in support of DoD's Everything over IP (EoIP) mandate and Telephony requirements including: Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), Voice over Secure Internet Protocol (VoSIP), Video Teleconferencing over Secure Internet Protocol (VTCoSIP), Telephony Unified Messaging System (TUMS), Regional Telephony Management System (RTMS), Navy Video Conferencing System (NVCS), NVCS Coalition (NVCS-C), Internet Protocol (IP) Trunking, Aegis Ashore, and Telephony systems infrastructure (e.g. cable plant). Telephony system installations and/or upgrades occur at facilities in accordance with requirements as identified by Navy Information Forces (NAVIFOR), Office of the Chief of Naval Operations (OPNAV), and Missile Defense Agency (MDA) (i.e. FLTNOCs, Fleet Telecommunications sites, and Aegis Ashore Sites).
Procurement and installation unit cost variances are based on the location of the region/site (CONUS,OCONUS), number of sites in the region, the various site architectures and requirements, the age and type of systems modernized, and user density (number of users). Telephony quantities represent the number of regions that are being replaced/modernized in the given Fiscal Year (FY). Regions: CONUS: Southwest, Pacific Northwest, Southeast, Northeast, Mid-Atlantic. OCONUS: Western Pacific, Guantanamo, Europe, Middle East.
- Collateral Equipment, Telephony MILCON (-$4.424M): Funding decrease in FY20 is the result of procurement and installation occurring in two phases to align with the MICLON transition schedule. Phase I (procurement and integration) in FY19 and Phase II (testing and installation) in FY20. In FY20, funding supports installation and testing of mission related Telephony equipment at the following shore sites: - MILCON P-913: NCTAMS LANT C4I - MILCON P-621: NCTAMS LANT Det Rota Spain
Collateral Equipment, MILCON Project P-013 (+$2.066M) includes: Funding supports procurement and installation of mission related command, control, communications, computers and intelligence/Information Technology (C4I/IT) equipment to new Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station Pacific (NCTAMSPAC) Facility in Wahiawa. Relocates the Navy Information Operations Command (NIOC) Hawaii from Pearl Harbor to Wahiawa because the current facility has no installed fire sprinklers; extensive termite damage in roof and had structural column failure; and is operating under multiple SCIF security waivers. Increase between FY19 and FY20 will support the procurement of Wahiawa information technology efforts to include both Genser and Top Secret configuration.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Next Generation Enterprise Network (NGEN) is the acquisition approach and contract vehicle used to manage the Navy Marine Corps Intranet (NMCI) enterprise network which will provide secure, net-centric data and services to Navy and Marine Corps personnel and represents the continuous evolution of information technology at the Department of Navy (DoN). Additionally NGEN provides security for the non-classified Internet Protocol (IP) Router Network (known as NIPRNET) and the classified Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRNET). NIPRNET is a private IP network used to exchange unclassified information, including information subject to controls on distribution, among the private network's users. SIPRNET is a system of interconnected computer networks used to transmit classified information (up to and including information classified SECRET) by packet switching over the "completely secure environment." NGEN forms the foundation for the DoN's future Naval Network Environment that will be interoperable with and leverage other Department of Defense-provided Net-Centric Enterprise Services.
The OCONUS Network (formerly Base Level Information Infrastructure (BLII), now referred to as "OCONUS" or "ONE-Net") will transition to the NGEN business operating model upon the award of the NGEN follow-on contract (NGEN-R). This will allow the Naval Enterprise Networks (NEN) to function as a common global network through the institution of a single approved service operating model.
Technology Refresh and Modernization Plan (TRMP): TRMP is a requirement performed by Naval Enterprise Networks (NEN) which focuses on upgrading the existing Hardware and or Software to mitigate End of Life, End of Support and End of Software Support issues in order to maintain network performance, Architecture/Solution Accreditations and network security.
TRMP involves the modernization and periodic replacement of NMCI hardware/software and assigned non-IT assets identified in the NGEN TRMP plan required to support network performance. The objective of TRMP is to improve and maintain network performance, increase network capacity based on project demand, improve security posture from vulnerabilities and integrate DoD and/or DoN mandates. NGEN assets are Government Owned/Contractor Operated (GO/CO). A significant amount of those assets have reached End-of-Life and are no longer supported by the vendors, which makes our infrastructure vulnerable to external cyber-attacks; and diminishes enterprise solutions performance and optimization. Our current infrastructure is aged and modernization is essential to improve storage capabilities to accommodate new emerging workforce requirements; maintain network performance, architecture/solution accreditations, and network security. The procurement of these assets will continue in FY18 and beyond. TRMP also allows the NEN program to insert and or augment new technology solutions (H/W and/or S/W) to meet evolving requirements (e.g. JRSS) and keep closer pace with industry advancements. Hence, future TRMP funding will be utilized to transition to 10GB networks. The final phase of ORT cybersecurity enhancements were procured in FY16 for deployment in FY17. Cyber Security enhancements previously funded with Operation Rolling Tide (ORT) funding will be procured and/or refreshed as part of TRMP baseline beginning in FY18.
OCONUS Layer 1 (L1) Fiber Optic Upgrades, Far East (FE): Install/upgrade OSP (Outside Plant) pathway and cabling in Far East NMCI OCONUS sites (Yokosuka Japan + remote sites, Atsugi Japan, Sasebo Japan, Diego Garcia, Okinawa Japan) in accordance with NCTSFE BCO (Naval Computer Telecom Station Far East Base Commanding Officer) Master Plan, and Premise Cabling Layer 1 to support direct connections from each building to a distribution switch in support of current and future Unified Capability (UC) and Cloud (O-365) related initiatives. Without infrastructure being updated the NMCI OCONUS network will become increasingly vulnerable as communications are required to transit less secure pathways and may be open for intercept or interference. If not funded, the network pathway infrastructure will not support newer technologies, faster speeds or the full range of network defense capabilities.
OCONUS Windows Server 2008 Operating System Eradication: Microsoft Windows 2008 servers/platforms (473 combined NIPR SIPR servers) will reach end of support (EoS) January 2020. The ONE-Net enterprise, is required to upgrade all 473 servers to the target OS Windows Server 2016 or OS Windows Server 2019 to bring improved Authority to Operate (ATO) and cyber security posture. Each server will become a CAT 1 vulnerability hit based on Cyber Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) guidelines forcing the ONE-Net program into a High Risk Escalation (HRE) Briefing situation. Windows Server 2016 or 2019 are the target OS, and will provide improved security, cloud enabling capabilities, administration accountability/control and software patches improving cyber security.
OCONUS Transition: Transition funding will provide for the security and technology improvements and sustainment efforts, to include systems/security engineering and integration, production, installation and implementation of network infrastructure, in support of the transition of ONE-NET into the NGEN business model. This will result in a fully integrated navy network with NIPR (unclassified) and SIPR (classified) enclaves operated via a controlled common operational approach as ONE-Net goes through the process of transition to the NMCI business model from both an operating model (GoGo/multivendor) and infrastructure perspective (aligning HW/SW/Capabilities to NMCI CONUS).
OCONUS Technical Refresh: OCONUS funding will provide for the technical refresh of network infrastructure that have reached end of life/support and now present security risks to the network. Antiquated PCs will be at the end of their final warranty. It will also provide the funding for systems/security engineering and integration, production, installation and implementation of hardware and software in support of the transition of ONE-NET into NGEN business model.
Network Devices and PC Warranties (of which 15,386 have already expired and been extended) will expire (end of support) at the end of calendar year 2020, driving a one-time increase of $24.2M to refresh 20,468 computers. Without extended support, each machine will experience a DISA CAT 1 Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) hit (Cyber risk) on the Enterprise and place site accreditations packages at risk, resulting in a High Risk Escalation (HRE) scenario.
OCONUS Piers Technical Refresh: In FY20 funding for OCONUS Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA) is realigned from LI 8164 to LI 3050.
Joint Regional Security Stack (JRSS): JRSS is a Joint Information Environment (JIE) initiative that consolidates Cybersecurity control points for the Department of Defense (DoD) and mission support organizations. JRSS will replace the existing Navy cyber protection boundaries allowing for a common and operable cyber defense network across all of the DoD. The Joint Information Environment (JIE) scope which included JRSS was laid out broadly in a series of Joint Chiefs of Staff Tank and Deputy Secretary Management Action Group (DMAG) decisions in 2012. DoD CIO, via the JIE EXCOM, has further refined the priorities of those tasks, consistent with the implementation strategy. JRSS is DoD's near term modernization priority, and is fielded as an Enterprise Service, as designated by the DoD CIO in November 2015. With the designation of JRSS as an Enterprise Service, the DoD CIO required JRSS be separately identified.
Collateral Equipment - MILCON Project P-013: Project P-013 provides Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF) space for three PACOM Cyber Protection Teams in Hawaii Wahiawa, which currently has inadequate SCIF space to meet USCYBERCOM standards.
Collateral Equipment - MILCON Project P-913: Project P-913 project combines the cyber defense missions from two buildings (M-51 and NH-95) into one 187,000 square foot integrated communications facility with SCIF capability at Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station Atlantic (NCTAMSLANT).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY20-24 funding for LI 8164 was reduced by a total of (-$9.96M) due to realignment of EPCA/PIERS from BLI 8164 to BLI 3050. This realignment included: realigning (-$4.96M) from OCONUS Piers Technical Refresh, as well as (-$5.00M) from the Technical Refresh Modernization Plan (TRMP).
CONUS TRMP (+$3.0M): The FY19-FY20 net growth for the Technical Refresh and Modernization Plan (TRMP)supports the Cable Plant outside plant/inside plant (OSP/ISP).
OCONUS Network Improvement (+$16.4M): Funding required to support one-time replacement of end-of-life/support operating system software on ONE-Net servers, along with Cloud enabling capabilities and services in order to provide enhanced cyber security posture, in support of ONE-Net's transition to NMCI (NGEN Contract). OCONUS Network Improvement efforts include:
- OCONUS Windows Server 2008 Operating System Eradication (+$5.5M): Funding required to support one-time replacement of end-of-life/support operating system software on ONE-Net servers, along with Cloud enabling capabilities and services in order to provide enhanced cyber security posture, in support of ONE-Net's transition to NMCI (NGEN Contract).
- OCOUNS Layer 1 (L1) Fiber Optic Upgrades, Far East (FE)($10.9M): Requirement includes fiber optic and copper cabling, patch panels, wall and/or floor mounted cabinets and racks, and construction of UFC (Unified Capabilities Framework) compliant telecommunications room in accordance with DoD 8500.1. This upgrade is required to execute critical time sensitive National Command Authority direct mission.
OCONUS Transition (+$0.14M): OCONUS Network (ONE-Net) will transition to the NGEN business model upon the award of the NGEN follow-on contract (NGEN-R). This will allow the Naval Enterprise Networks (NEN) to function as a common global network through the institution of a single approved service operating model in conjunction with the current Navy Marine Corps Intranet (NMCI) network. In essence, the CONUS and OCONUS networks are intended to merge into a single allocated baseline as part of the NGEN-R contract.
- The FY20 OCONUS Transition funding increase will provide for the security and technology improvements and sustainment efforts of the network as ONE-Net goes through the process of transition to the NGEN business model from both an operating model (GoGo/multi-vendor) and infrastructure perspective (aligning HW/SW/Capabilities to NMCI CONUS).
OCONUS Technical Refresh (+$19.5M) includes: - OCONUS funding will provide for the technical refresh of network infrastructure that have reached end of life/support and now present security risks to the network. Antiquated PCs will be at the end of their final warranty. It will also provide the funding for systems/security engineering and integration, production, installation and implementation of hardware and software in support of the transition of ONE-NET into NGEN business model.
- The FY19-FY20 Technical Refresh will fund the refresh and installation of 20,468 end points (PCs/laptops). PC Warranties (of which 15,386 have already expired and been extended) will expire (end of support) at the end of calendar year 2020, driving a necessary refresh 20,468 computers. Failure to replace these machines will result in a DISA CAT 1 Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) hit (Cyber risk) on the Enterprise and place site accreditations packages at risk, resulting in a High Risk Escalation (HRE) scenario.
NCTAMS LANT C4I (-$2.4M): - The decrease is due to the MILCON Project P-913 for completion of project - Shore Based Enterprise Network Enhancements: This funding supports the procurement and installation of NMCI infrastructure to the new Naval Computer and Telecommunications Area Master Station Atlantic (NCTAMSLANT) Facility (MILCON P-913).
Collateral Equipment - MILCON Project P-013 (+$0.362M): - Increase from FY19 to FY20 will support equipment purchases associated with the development and refurbishment of Sensitive Compartmented Information Facilities (SCIF) to ensure information sharing is executed in a controlled environment and at the appropriate classification levels for the Cyber Mission Forces Teams. MILCON Project P-013 provides SCIF space for three PACOM Cyber Protection Teams, in Hawaii Wahiawa, which currently has inadequate SCIF space to meet USCYBERCOM standards.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
OPN-8 Budget Line Item (BLI) 9020 Spares and Repair Parts Budget, provides funding to procure spares for systems and equipment budgeted in Budget Activities (BA) 01-07. This budget is a follow on account, which supports the End-Item Hardware procurements.
It is further broken down within three separate sub-line items: 10 (9020-10) Initial Spares, 90 (9020-90) Vendor-Direct (Replenishment) Spares, and 20 (9020-20) for Coordinated Shipboard Allowance List (COSAL) Outfitting Spares. Sub-line items 10 and 90 collectively are referred to as Interim Spares.
During this Interim phase, Initial Spares are procured by NAVSEA Program Offices and other SYSCOMs to support newly procured hardware installations. This material may include, but is not limited to, Installation and Check out (INCO-I/INCO-R) Spares, On-Board Repair Parts (OBRP), Maintenance Assistance Modules (MAM) and Interim Depot Stock. INCOs are tools, hardware, spares, and repair parts provided with end-items to be used during installation and check out of a newly installed end-item/System. OBRPs are an initial lay-in of spares and repair parts to support new system installations. MAMs are plug-in/unplug, remove and replace items, such as circuit cards, used for diagnostic purposes in performing corrective maintenance on end-items. Interim Depot stock, also known as Vendor Direct/Replenishment Spares, provide Appropriation Purchase Account (APA) material for planned equipment replacement programs and supports the depot level maintenance turn-a-round time and depot through put capabilities.
During the Outfitting phase, material procurements buy out material from the DoD supply system to provide OBRPs for allowance increases in initial range and depth, maintenance and modernizations efforts, and configuration changes.
In addition to specific requirements identified above, the overall 9020 Spares and Repair parts budget supports Special Programs such as Q-COSAL range and depth repair parts, special tools, chemicals and other miscellaneous portable items necessary for operation, overhaul, and repair of reactor plant equipment for each nuclear powered hull; Gold Disk micro/miniature 2M repair; Portable Firefighting Equipment; and Damage Control Locker parts.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Justification for FY20 increases, all amounts delineate program increases compared to FY19.
Initial Spares
0670/ (Initial)Other Navigation equipment- (Initial) Increase procures spares for AN/WSN-7 ($0.27 million)
0840 / Sub Periscope, Imaging and Supt Equip Prog - (Initial) Increase procures spares for: Technical Insertion, Electronic Warfare Enhanced Upgrade, Imaging Block Upgrade and the Type 20 Task Oriented Technology Insertion Mast (TOTIM) Mast. ($14.95 million)
0900 / DDG MOD - (Initial) Increase procures initial spares to support installation of Gun Controls Systems ($0.98 million), multi-Mission Signal Processor ($1.07M), and AN/SQQ-89 TI18 mods, ($1.16 million), MK41 w/ESSM ($0.771 million).
0946 / LPD Class Support Equipment - (Initial) Increase procures spares to support installation of HM&E ($0.1 million), electrical($0.06 million), and survivability ($0.07 million) modifications.
0977 / Underwater EOD Programs - (Initial) Increase procures spares to support Underwater Unmanned Vehicle (UUV) Advanced Sensors (Autonomous Large Area Sonar (ATLAS) and Small Synthetic Aperture Minehunter (SSAM)), VSW/EOD auxiliary equipment upgrades ($5.5 million), and marine mammal program equipment, ($1.3 million).
1600 / LCS Common Mission Module Equipment - (Initial) Increase procures spares for MPCE Sonar Processing systems on (4) LCS ships ($0.897 million); (2) Shipboard Over-the-Horizon Communication systems ($0.080 million)
1601 / LCS MCM Mission Modules - (Initial) Increase procures spares for new MCM systems that include: AN/AQS-20C mine-hunting sonar systems ($2.4 million), and SMCM Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUV) Knifefish systems ($4.5 million).
1604 / LCS In-Service Modernization - (Initial) Increase procures spares for mandatory safety design changes ($0.63 million), Cyber Security remediation actions ($0.8 million), obsolescence and reliability resolution ($2.5 million) modernization efforts to the HM&E, C4I, and Combat Systems onboard (8) LCS ships scheduled for availabilities in FY20.
2150 / SSN Acoustic - (Initial) Increase procures spares for Low Cost Conformal Array ($0.7 million) and Towed Systems ECPs ($1.05 million)
2614 / Adv Tact Data Link Sys (ATDLS) - (Initial) Increase procures spares for command and control processor (C2P) tech refresh($0.144 million) and Link 16 MIDS on Ship (MOS) upgrades ($0.135 million) due to MSD being shifted from SEP 20 and JUN 19 to FEB 22 and MAR 21 respectively.
2622 / Minesweeping System Replacement - (Initial) Increase procures spares and INCOs for (2) additional SMCM UUV (Knifefish) systems being installed onboard LCS ships ($0.66 million).
2624 / Shallow Water CM Ship - (Initial) Increase procures spares and INCOs for (1) additional COBRA system onboard LCS ships ($0.44 million).
2657 / NAVSTAR GPS RECEIVER (SPACE) - (Initial) Increase procures spares for (6) additional systems for Global Positioning System Based Positioning, Navigation, and Timing Service (GPNTS) ($0.11 million). In FY17, DON leadership approved rapid fielding for GPNTS to meet FOC by FY26 as opposed to FY32. Funding supports INCO spares and pre-MSD depot support for additional fielded units.
2830 / Afloat ATC Equip - (Initial) Increase procures (2) spares for SPN-46 BLK IV upgrade and (1) spare for SPN-50 V(1), which mitigates obsolescence issues in the Automatic Carrier Landing Systems (ACLS), ($1.221 million). ACLS provides precision electronic guidance for landing suitably equipped aircraft under all weather conditions on CVNs, LHA/LHD class ships and selected Naval Air Stations.
2867 / Joint Precision Approach and Landing System (JPALS) - (Initial) Increase procures (8) spares to support primary precision approach and landing system for CVN and LHA/D class ships to support aircraft without SPN-46 ACLS capability, ($8.137 million)
2914 / Distributed Common Ground System-Navy - (Initial) Increase procures spares for (2) Product Improvements Afloat, (4) Increment 2 Afloat procurements, (1) Increment 2 Ashore procurement ($0.397 million)
2915 / CANES - (Initial) Increase procures spares for afloat and ashore installations and tech insertions. CANES Hardware 1.2 (Upgrade from Hardware 1.0 for new class system variants), includes servers, workstations, and network storage, Limited Development Deployment (LDD) CANES architecture driving increases in interim spares requirements. HW 1.2 lays the groundwork for the next revision of the Video Teleconference hardware SX-80 adding 1080P video support for H265 supporting future bandwidth efficiencies capabilities and replaces the C60 End-of-Life system supported spares. ($1.741 million)
2950 / Network Tactical Common Data Link (CDL)- increase procures to spares for four (4) Communications Data Link System (CDLS) Technical Refresh (TR) systems on CVN platforms ($0.208 million)
3620 / Coast Guard Equipment - (Initial) Increase procures spares for Navy-type, Navy Owned (NTNO) equipment Multi-Mode Radar and Mk20 Mod1 Electro Optical Sighting Systems for Offshore Patrol Cutter (WMSM) requirements. ($0.226 million)
4213 / Aircraft Support Equipment - (Initial) Increase also procures spares for engineering change proposals for (48) Aircraft Launch and Recovery Equipment, Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG), and Electromagnetic Aircraft Landing/Launching (EMAL) systems. ($0.646 million)
4248 / Legacy Airborne MCM - (Initial) Increase procures spares for Airborne Mine Counter Measures (AMCM) and Aviation Mine Neutralization System (AMNS) engineering change proposals due to obsolescence and safety design changes. ($0.289 million)
5420 / SSN Combat Control Systems - (Initial) Increase procures spares for 2-year-cycle system upgrades. Technical insertion 18 ($1.08 million) Technical insertion 20 ($1.01 million)
5509 / Explosive Ordnance Disposal Equipment - (Initial) Increase procures spares to support (602) Counter Radio-Controlled Improvised Explosive Device (IED) Electronic Warfare systems. ($2.280 million)
5664 / Surface Training Equipment - (Initial) Increase procures spares in support of LCS trainers and (14) Battle Force Tactical Trainers (BFTT) ship sets: AN/USQ-T46, AN/USQ-T52. ($1.168 million)
6033 / Amphibious Equipment & Rolling Stock (Initial)- Increase funds spares to support Logistics Over the Shore equipment procured in prior fiscal years. ($0.132 million)
9501 / Rolling Stock - (Initial) Increase procures spares to support changes to Navy rolling stock inventory. ($0.08 million)
0920 / Outfitting (COSAL) Increase buys out supply system material in support of all post material support date (MSD) installations across the Navy Enterprise for Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT), Ship Signal Exploration Equipment (SSEE), Cruiser Modernization, Shipboard Tactical Communications, AN/SLQ-32, Ship Missile Support Equipment, AN/SQQ-89 ASW Combat System, Items less than $5M (BA-1 and BA-2), and other OPN funded end-item programs as well as material to support expeditionary programs. Outfitting also buys out material procured as range and depth increases for allowances/onboard repair parts (OBRP). ($39.6 million)
In addition increase funds special programs to improve supply readiness of systems: Ship Signal Exploitation Equipment (SSEE) SSEE MODS readiness based sparing (RBS) BACKFIT Special program: Delayed RBS run has resulted in 6 DDGs not receiving their OBRPs. ($2.535 million)
AN/SLQ-32 (V) 6 BLK2 RBS BACKFIT Special Program: Original Equipment Manufacturer engineering estimates were used for initial RBS, but current complement of OBRPs only supports approximately 25% of failures. Current Operational Availability is less than 0.4. Re-run of RBS indicates Operational Availability will increase from 0.38 to almost 0.7. This supports 13 ships. ($2.470 million)
9924 / Spares for NAVSEA - (Outfitting) Increase procures additional micro/miniature repair, damage control and portable firefighting equipment.($3.157 million)
9925 / Spares for NAVFAC - (Outfitting) - Increase funds spares for tactical vehicles and construction & maintenance equipment for expeditionary units. ($0.361 million)
VENDOR DIRECT Spares (Replenishment)
0942 / Virginia Class Support Equipment - (REPLEN) - Increase is reflects combination of SEAWOLF and Virginia class Advanced Equipment Replacement Program (AERP). AERP was originally established to assist in shortening the time required to accomplish the overhaul and/or conversion of SSBN submarines from Polaris to Poseidon configuration. The program has since expanded and evolved into a system for supporting programmed and condition based maintenance for all SSN depot availabilities. Consists of 53 NSNs with average unit cost of ($0.460 million). ($13.554 million)
1603 / LCS SUW Mission Modules - (REPLEN) Increase procures spares for MK50 Gun Mission Module and 2J COG spares to support LCS SUW operational missions. ($2.424 million)
2624 / Shallow Water MCM - (REPLEN) Increase procures spares for appropriations purchases account (APA) material in support of Coastal Battlefield Reconnaissance and Analysis (COBRA) operations. ($0.128 million)
5111 / Ship Gun Systems Equipment - (REPLEN) Increase procures 2J spares equipment for the MK20 Electro-Optical Sensor System (EOSS) and MK46 Optical Sight System (OSS). Equipment is seeing increased unplanned usage. ($0.867 million)
